Title.En: Critical Cultural Awareness in Migration societies

NoteLiteral.En:
For whom?
This module is on a Master’s level. Admission requirements are Bachelor in Early Childhood studies or other relevant education at Bachelor level. Documentation needs to be provided in the application.

Contact persons: Gunnar Magnus Eidsvåg gunnar.m.eidsvag@uis.no (academic) and Olav Kylland olav.kylland@uis.no (administrative)

Admission requirements
You must upload an official English copy of your transcript of records.
You must upload a short motivation letter (no more than one A4 page)
You must fill inn all the fields in the Personal Information registration form (see section "The application process". This information is required to complete the admission process at University of Stavanger.

Admission process
We process applications toward the end of the application period. If your application is accepted, you will receive an offer sent to your ECIU email address. Please remember to check your ECIU email and spam folder regularly, and note that you have 7 days to accept the offer.

Description.En:
This study module aims at enhancing cultural awareness as a key skill in Early Childhood setting.

Globalization has the last decades turned national and local communities into migrant societies. ECEC is an institution in which children, guardians, parents, and staff from various backgrounds and with multiple belongings meet. This gives ECEC a key role in creating inclusion and belonging in dynamic communities influenced by local and global concerns.

The course will enrich students’ knowledge and skills for leading and guiding processes of creating belonging in children’s groups, cooperating with a diverse group of parents/guardians, finding practical, enjoyable, and efficient ways of working as professional staff requires high level of intercultural competence.

NoteLiteral.En: After completing the course, the student should be able to apply their research-based knowledge regarding culture, play and belonging to relevant practical situations; develop and scientifically evaluate inclusive practices in encounters with children, parents and colleagues; detect, analyze, and counteract discriminatory practices; create brave and safe spaces to enable authentic dialogues; have a resource-oriented approach towards diversity.

After completing the course, the candidate should have advanced knowledge of the concepts of diversity, inclusion and belonging and early childhood education practices associated with them; the complexity of migrant societies with multifaceted identities and belongings; how ECEC practices and material equipment such as books, toys and art can promote inclusion and counteract hegemony; how to analyze children cultures and develop sociological theory of interethnic play; the role of kindergarten as a meeting place for children, guardians, parents, and staff, and how to create belonging for all involved.

PrefLabel.En: respect the diversity of cultural values and norms

NoteLiteral.En: After completing the course, the student should be able to give an account of, analyze, and translate theory of belonging into practice; develop theory and reflect on power and privileges; create communities in a diverse ECEC that enables equity, solidarity, and freedom; discern power structures within languages and between language users; develop the ECEC as an arena in which belonging to the local community is created for the whole family.

Title.En: Critical Cultural Awareness in Migration societies
Critical Cultural Awareness in Migration societies

MoreInformation.NoteLiteral:
**For whom?**

This module is on a Master’s level. Admission requirements are Bachelor in Early Childhood studies or other relevant education at Bachelor level. Documentation needs to be provided in the application.

Contact persons: Gunnar Magnus Eidsvåg gunnar.m.eidsvag@uis.no (academic) and Olav Kylland olav.kylland@uis.no (administrative)

**Format**

The course is a blended intensive program (BIP), and students must attend both the online and the in-person sessions at University of Stavanger campus.

BIP code: 2024-1-NO01-KA131-HED-000211266-3

**When?**

- First online session: 20.03.2025
- Last online session: 30.05.2025
- 5 day in-person course in Stavanger: 07.04-11.04.2025

**Course content and exam arrangements:**

- The students will be engaged in lectures by international expert-teachers, seminars, on-line seminars and work groups, worlds café, and student presentations. Furthermore, the course will connect theory and practical knowledge through a collaboration seminar in Jåttå University kindergarten.
- There will be an essay-based exam, which can be written individually (2500 - 3000 words) or in pairs (4000-4500 words). The essay must be written according to guidelines provided during the course. The content is a discussion of critical cultural awareness for school/kindergarten in migration societies.
- The exam is stipulated to 20 working days. The topic is developed during the five course days. The exam starts on Monday the week after the course and is due 20 working days later.

**Suggested readings**

Yuval Davis, N. (2006) "Belonging and the politics of belonging" in Patterns of Prejudice, 40(3):196-213

Zachrisen, B. (2018) Recognizing Children’s Diverse Backgrounds: Democracy and Equality in Preschool. In Johansson, E., Emilson, A. & Puroila, A.M. (eds.) Values Education in Early Childhood Settings. 231–247.

**Funding to travel?**

Please contact your local/home university to check out the possibility to apply for funding for the travel and stay (mobility support). There might be an early deadline for this, so check this out as soon as you can.

**Housing and travel**

Due to the difficult housing situation in Stavanger, UiS cannot provide accommodation for shortterm international students. Therefore, you will have to find housing on the private market.

Please note that you are responsible for organizing your own travel.

This study module aims at enhancing cultural awareness as a key skill in an Early Childhood setting. Globalization has, in the last decades, transformed national and local communities into migrant societies. Early Childhood Education and Care (ECEC) is an institution where children, guardians, parents, and staff from various backgrounds and with multiple affiliations come together. This gives ECEC a key role in creating inclusion and a sense of belonging in dynamic communities influenced by local and global concerns. The course will enrich students’ knowledge and skills for leading and guiding processes of creating a sense of belonging in children’s groups, cooperating with a diverse group of parents/guardians. Finding practical, enjoyable, and efficient ways of working as professional staff requires a high level of intercultural competence.

**For whom?**

This module is on a Master’s level. You must have completed 180 ECTS, preferably within Early Childhood studies or other relevant education. Documentation needs to be provided in the application.

Contact persons:

- Gunnar Magnus Eidsvåg gunnar.m.eidsvag@uis.no (academic)
- Olav Kylland olav.kylland@uis.no (administrative)

**Admission requirements**

- You must upload an official English copy of your transcript of records.
- You must upload a short motivation letter (no more than one A4 page)
- You must fill inn all the fields in this form: [personal information registration](https://forms.office.com/e/NWYzspN06j). This information is required to complete the admission process at University of Stavanger.

**Admission process**

We process applications toward the end of the application period. If your application is accepted, you will receive an offer sent to your ECIU email address.

Please remember to check your ECIU email and spam folder regularly, and note that you have 7 days to accept the offer.
